page.title: List of people from Harlem, New York

revisions.rev:
{{Orphan|date=February 2010}} This is a '''list of people from [[Harlem]], New York'''.
== The early period (pre-1920) == *[[John James Audubon]] â Naturalist<ref name="gillpost">[http://harlembespoke.blogspot.com/2011/01/remember-harlem-by-jonathan-gill.html REMEMBER: Harlem by Jonathan Gill post] Harlem+Bespoke, January 24, 2011</ref> *Frederic Alexander Birmingham â Editor of ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine from 1945â1957, grew up in Harlem<ref>''It Was Fun While it Lasted,'' Frederic Alexander Birmingham, 1960</ref> *[[Aaron Burr]] â Vice President<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Richard Croker]] â [[Tammany Hall]] politician<ref>''Malcolm,'' Bruce Perry, Station Hill, 1991. page 154</ref>, lived at 26 Mount Morris Park West<ref name="gill127">''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.127</ref> *[[James Reese Europe]] â musician, credited with inventing jazz. 67 West 133rd Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.220</ref><ref name="gillpost"/> *[[F. Scott Fitzgerald|F. Scott]] and [[Zelda Fitzgerald]] â author and wife<ref name="NYMag20060814">"Star Map", ''New York'' Magazine, August 14, 2006, p.35</ref> *[[Thomas Francis Gilroy|Thomas Gilroy]] - New York mayor<ref name="gill127"/> *[[Alexander Hamilton]] â politician, lived in Harlem at the end of his life *[[Hubert Harrison]] â "The Father of Harlem Radicalism" *[[Scott Joplin]] â pianist/composer, lived at 133 West 138th Street in 1916, then at 163 West 131st Street until his death in 1917. Had a studio at 160 West 133rd Street.<ref>"Tracing Scott Joplin's Life Through His Addresses", ''New York Times,'' Real Estate, p.2, February 4, 2007</ref> *[[Alfred Henry Lewis]] - cowboy author<ref name="gill128">''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.128</ref> *[[Vincent James McMahon]] - Founder of the World Wide Wrestling Federation. *[[Paul Meltsner]] - WPA era painter amd muralist grew up in Harlem *[[Thomas Nast]] â artist<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Philip A. Payton, Jr.]] - real estate entrepreneur. Lived at 13 West 131st Street.<ref>[http://ephemeralnewyork.wordpress.com/2011/02/09/the-man-who-became-the-father-of-harlem/ Ephemeral New York]</ref> *[[Norman Rockwell]] â lived as a child at 789 St. Nicholas Avenue.<ref name="onestop"/> *[[Norman Thomas]] - radical activist<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.158</ref> *[[Daniel Tiemann]] - New York mayor<ref name="gill87">''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.87</ref> *[[Robert Van Wyck]] - New York mayor<ref name="gill127"/> *[[Cornelius Van Wyck Lawrence]] - New York mayor<ref name="gill87"/>
== Jewish, Italian, Irish Harlem (c. 1900 - 1930) == [[File:MoeBergGoudeycard.jpg| thumb| 180px |[[Moe Berg]]]] *[[Sholem Aleichem]] - writer, 110 Lenox Avenue<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.146</ref> *[[Moe Berg]] â Major League Baseball catcher, and spy *[[Milton Berle]] â born in a five-story walkup at 68 West 118th Street.<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.165</ref> *[[Fanny Brice]] - actress, houses at West 128th Street and West 118th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.163</ref> *[[Art Buchwald]] - writer<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.158</ref> *[[Bennett Cerf]] - publisher<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.137</ref> *[[Morris Raphael Cohen]] - philosopher, 498 West 135th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.151</ref> *[[Don Giosuele Galluci]] - gangster, 318 East 109th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.151</ref> *[[George Gershwin|George]] and [[Ira Gershwin]]: composers, grew up in Harlem. Lived at 108 West 111th and other addresses.<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.164</ref> George wrote his first hit song, "Swanee", at his home at 520 W. 144 Street in 1919.<ref name="onestop">[http://www.harlemonestop.com/organization.php?id=115 Harlem One-Stop]</ref> *[[Lorenz Hart]] - lyricist, 59 West 119th Street.<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.136</ref> *[[Oscar Hammerstein I]] â inventor and theatrical entrepreneur, lived at 333 Edgecombe Avenue<ref name="onestop"/> *[[Oscar Hammerstein II]] â writer and theatrical producer, addresses on East 116th Street and 112th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.138</ref> *[[Harry Houdini]] â magician, lived at 278 West 113th Street from 1904 until his death in 1926<ref>"The Top of the Park", ''New York'' Magazine, February 5, 2007, p.44</ref> *[[Frank Hussey]] - Olympian, 129th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.149</ref> *[[Burt Lancaster]] - actor<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.158</ref> *[[Solomon Libin]] - writer in Yiddish<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.146</ref> *[[Marx Brothers]] - comedians, 239 East 114th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.165</ref> *[[Arthur Miller]] â playwright, 45 West 110th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.166</ref><ref>Arthur Miller Files, at University of Michigan</ref> *[[Giuseppe Morello]] - gangster, 323 East 107th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.152</ref> *[[Al Pacino]] â Academy Award winning actor *[[Richard Rogers]] - composer, 3 West 120th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.137</ref><ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Henry Roth]] - writer, 108 East 119th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.146</ref> *[[Moses Reicherson]] - linguist, East 106th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.147</ref> *[[Yossele Rosenblatt]] - celebrated cantor<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.148</ref> *[[Ignazio Lupo]] - counterfeiter, gangster<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.152</ref> *[[Jessie Sampter]] - poet<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.149</ref> *[[Pasquarelli Spinelli]] - gangster, 318 East 109th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.151</ref> *[[Arthur Hays Sulzberger|Arthur Sulzberger]] - publisher of the ''[[New York Times]]'' <ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.148</ref> *[[Henrietta Szold]] - founder of [[Hadassah]]<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.149</ref> *[[Morello crime family|Vincent and Ciro Terranova]] - gangsters, 352 East 116th Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.153</ref>
== The Harlem Renaissance and World War II (1920â1945) == [[File:409 Edgecomb Av jeh.JPG|thumb|409 Edgecombe Avenue]] *[[Louis Armstrong]] â Musician<ref name="HUSAlangston">"My Early Days in Harlem", Langston Hughes, in ''Harlem U.S.A.,'' ed. John Henrick Clarke, 1971 edition, p.58</ref> *[[Count Basie]] â Bandleader and pianist. Lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="maahcg">''Manhattan African-American History and Culture Guide,'' Museum of the City of New York</ref><ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[George Wilson Becton]] â Religious cult leader<ref>"Four Men of Harlem â The Movers and the Shakers", in ''Harlem, U.S.A.,'' John Henrik Clarke, 1971 edition, p.251</ref> *[[Julius Bledsoe]] â Singer, lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue<ref name="westharlemcpo">[http://www.westharlemcpo.org/history/history_2.shtml Hamilton Heights â West Harlem Community Preservation Organization]</ref> *[[Arna Bontemps]] â Writer *[[William Stanley Braithwaite]] â Poet and essayist, lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue<ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[Eunice Carter]] â New York state judge, lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue<ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[John Henrik Clarke]] â Editor of ''Freedomways Magazine'' and of several books, sometime professor. Moved to Harlem in 1933.<ref name="HUSA">''Harlem U.S.A,'' introductory essay to 1993 edition, John Henrik Clarke, A&B Book Publishers</ref> *[[Collyer brothers]] â Compulsive hoarders, lived in a townhouse at 128th Street and Fifth Avenue in Harlem their entire adult lives *[[Countee Cullen]] â Poet<ref name="HUSAlangston"/> *[[Aaron Douglas]] â Painter, lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue<ref name="westharlemcpo"/><ref name="HUSA"/> *[[W. E. B. Du Bois]] â Activist, writer. Lived at 409 Edgecombe.<ref name="maahcg"/><ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[Duke Ellington]] â Composer, band leader. Lived on Riverside Drive in Harlem and, at another point, at 555 Edgecombe.<ref name="maahcg"/><ref name="ng1977">"To Live In Harlem", Frank Hercules, ''National Geographic,'' February 1977, p.178+</ref> *[[Father Divine]] â Religious leader<ref name="ng1977"/> Lived in several locations in Harlem, including on [[Astor Row]], and maintained offices at 20 West 115th Street<ref>"Four Men of Harlem â The Movers and the Shakers", in ''Harlem, U.S.A.,'' John Henrik Clarke, 1971 edition, p.256</ref> *[[Rudolph Fisher]] â Writer<ref name="HUSA"/> *[[Marcus Garvey]] - Political figure, black separatist. Home at 235 West 131st Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.248</ref> *[[Marcelino Manuel da Graca|Charles Manuel "Sweet Daddy" Grace]] â Evangelist, born in Cape Verde Islands but became prominent in Harlem in the 1920s<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Lillian Harris Dean]] â Entrepreneur known as Pigfoot Mary *[[Lionel Hampton]] â Jazz musician. Lived in Harlem through World War II and for some years thereafter.<ref name="HUSA"/> *[[Hubert Harrison]] â "The Father of Harlem Radicalism" *[[Coleman Hawkins]] â Musician, saxophone player. Lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="booksNYC">"Making a Home, and a Haven for Books", Jim Dwyer, ''New York Times,'' August 11, 2007</ref> *[[Johnnie Hodges]] â Musician, lived at 555 Edgecombe.<ref name="maahcg"/> *[[Billie Holiday]] â Singer, lived with her mother at 108 West 139th Street<ref name="indep97">"The New Heyday of Harlem", Tessa Souter, The Independent on Sunday, June 8, 1997</ref> *[[Casper Holstein]] â Gangster *[[Lena Horne]] â Singer and actress. Lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="booksNYC"/> *[[Langston Hughes]] â Writer<ref name="NYMag20060814"/> *[[Zora Neale Hurston]] â Writer<ref name="NYMag20060814"/> *[[Ellsworth "Bumpy" Johnson|Bumpy Johnson]] â Gangster, lived in Lenox Terrace at 132nd Street and Lenox Avenue near the end of his life.<ref name="nym20070115">"Chairman of the Money", ''New York Magazine,'' January 15, 2007, p.20</ref> *[[James P. Johnson]] â Pianist *[[James Weldon Johnson]] â Author, activist, composer. Lived at 187 West 135th Street.<ref name="maahcg"/> *[[Donald Jones (actor)]] â Actor and dancer born in Harlem but moved to the Netherlands *[[Fiorello H. LaGuardia|Fiorello La Guardia]] â New York Mayor, from East Harlem *[[Cora La Redd]] â Dancer<ref name="HUSAlangston"/> *[[Alain Locke]] â Editor<ref name="HUSAlangston"/> *[[Joe Louis]] â Boxer, lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue<ref name="booksNYC"/> *[[Claude McKay]] â Poet and novelist. Born in Jamaica but moved to Harlem and wrote the famous novel ''[[Home to Harlem]]'', West 131st Street<ref>''Harlem'', Jonathan Gill, p.223</ref> *[[Florence Mills]] â Entertainer *[[Adam Clayton Powell, Sr.]] â Religious, civic leader<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[A. Philip Randolph]] â Activist, labor organizer *[[Paul Robeson]] â Singer and actor, lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="maahcg"/><ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[Bill Robinson|Bill "Bojangles" Robinson]] â Dancer, lived on [[Strivers' Row]].<ref name="maahcg"/> *[[Willie "The Lion" Smith]] â Pianist *[[Stephanie St. Clair]] â Criminal leader, lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref>"409 Edgecombe, Baseball, and Madame St. Clair", Katherine Butler Jones, in ''The Harlem Reader,'' 2003</ref> *[[Wallace Thurman]] â Writer<ref name="HUSAlangston"/> *[[Jean Toomer]] â Writer<ref name="HUSA"/> *[[James Van Der Zee]] â Photographer<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Fats Waller]] â Pianist, born at 107 West 134th Street<ref>Harlem, Jonathan Gill, p.233</ref> *[[Madam C.J. Walker]] â Philanthropist and tycoon *[[A'Lelia Walker]] â Socialite and businesswoman *[[Ethel Waters]] â Singer, actress. Born in Chester, Pennsylvania *[[Walter Francis White]] â Civil rights leader<ref name="bootsie">"How Bootsie Was Born", Ollie Harrison, in ''Harlem U.S.A.'', John Henrik Clarke, ed., 1971, p.75 (note, this is a weak source, as it is a reference in a fictional story. A better source should be found.)</ref> *[[Bert Williams]] â Vaudeville actor. Born in Antigua. Died in 1922, near the start of the Harlem Renaissance. *[[Mary Lou Williams]] â Pianist, lived at 63 Hamilton Terrace<ref name="indep97"/>
== Famous after World War II == *[[James Baldwin (writer)|James Baldwin]] â Novelist, lived at one time at 131st Street and Adam Clayton Powell Blvd. (which was called "seventh avenue" when Baldwin still lived there)<ref>"A Talk to Harlem Teachers", James Baldwin, in ''Harlem USA,'' ed. John Henrik Clarke, 1971, p.173</ref> *[[Romare Bearden]] â Artist, primarily working in collage. *[[Harry Belafonte]] â Calypso musician *[[Claude Brown]] â Novelist, wrote ''Manchild in the Promised Land'' *[[Ron Brown (U.S. politician)|Ron Brown]] â U.S. Secretary of Commerce, grew up in the [[Hotel Theresa]].<ref>''Meet Me at the Theresa : The Story of Harlem's Most Famous Hotel,'' Sondra Kathryn Wilson, 2004</ref> *[[Kareem Campbell]] â Pro Skateboarder *[[George Carlin]] - Comedian, 121st Street between Amsterdam and Broadway<ref>[http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2011/09/george_carlin_s.php Village Voice online], September 7, 2011</ref> *[[Jimmy Castor]] â R&B/funk bandleader *[[Chevy Chase]] â comedian, raised in East Harlem.<ref>"Bah Humbug", Cindy Adams, ''The New York Post,'' December 6, 2007</ref> *[[Kenneth Clark (psychologist)|Dr. Kenneth Clark]] â Psychologist and activist, lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[Evelyn Cunningham]] â civil-rights-era journalist and aide to Gov. [[Nelson A. Rockefeller]] of New York<ref>"Evelyn Cunningham, Civil Rights Reporter, Dies at 94," Daniel Lovering, ''The New York Times,'' April 29, 2010</ref> *[[Jules Dassin]] â Movie director<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Benjamin J. Davis]] â New York city councilman, ultimately sent to jail for violations of the [[Smith Act]]<ref name="HUSA"/> *[[Ossie Davis]] â Actor, lived in Harlem in the late 1930s and mid-1940s *[[Sammy Davis, Jr.]] â Singer, member of [[Rat Pack]], born in [[Harlem Hospital]] in 1925.<ref>plaque outside the Harlem Hospital</ref> *[[Roy DeCarava]] â Photographer, born in Harlem in 1919.<ref>Museum of Contemporary Photography at Columbia College Chicago. [http://www.mocp.org/collections/permanent/decarava_roy.php Roy DeCarava.] Accessed August 4, 2009.</ref> * [[Wanda De Jesus]] (born August 26, 1960) is an American actress. *[[David Dinkins]] - Mayor of New York, lived in the Riverton Houses.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/nyregion/in-harlem-buildings-reminders-of-a-bubble-and-a-collapse.html "In Harlem Buildings, Reminders of Easy Money and the Financial Crisis,"] Charles V. Bagli, ''The New York Times,'' June 9, 2011</ref> *[[Ralph Ellison]] â Novelist, wrote ''Invisible Man,'' about a man who moves from the deep south to Harlem. Lived at 730 Riverside Drive in Harlem.<ref>monument outside 730 Riverside Drive</ref> *[[Erik Estrada]] â Actor, from East Harlem *Jack Geiger â Physician, cofounder of [[Physicians for Social Responsibility]]; lived with Canada Lee for a year at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="kos">"Kindness of Strangers", ''This American Life,'' September 12, 1997</ref> *[[Althea Gibson]] â Professional tennis player. Lived at 115 West 143rd Street.<ref name="maahcg"/> *[[Oscar Hammerstein II]] â Writer and theatrical producer<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[W. C. Handy]] â Composer and bandleader, lived on [[Strivers' Row]] in Harlem towards the end of his life.<ref name="maahcg"/> *Bennie Harris â Musician, trumpet<ref name="HUSAmusic"/> *[[Lorenz Hart]] â Lyricist<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Evan Hunter]] (a.k.a. "Ed McBain") â writer, grew up in East Harlem.<ref>''Metropolis Found: New York Is Book Country 25th Anniversary Collection,'' 2003</ref> *[[Roy Innis]] â Head of the [[Congress of Racial Equality]]. Lived in Harlem but ultimately moved to Brooklyn. "Forget Harlem. Brooklyn is now the world's black capital."<ref>"City Hall Holds The Key. Harlem's renaissance finds lots of friends, and a few foes", ''Christian Science Monitor,'' March 12, 1987</ref> *[[JTG]] â WWE Superstar *LeRoi Jones/[[Amiri Baraka]] â Dancer/poet/activist * [[June Jordan]] - Caribbean American poet, novelist, journalist, biographer, dramatist, teacher and committed activist *Charles Kenyatta â Activist, pastor, bodyguard and confidant of Malcolm X<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Canada Lee]] â Actor, lived at 555 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="kos"/> *[[Frankie Lymon]] â Lead tenor of [[The Teenagers]], best known for the song, "[[Why Do Fools Fall in Love (song)|Why Do Fools Fall in Love?]]" *[[Ben E. King]] â Soul singer and former lead tenor of [[The Drifters]], best known for the song, "[[Stand by Me (song)|Stand By Me]]" *[[Frank Lucas (criminal)|Frank Lucas]] â Drug dealer *[[Carl McCall]] â One-time New York State Senator, and Comptroller of New York State<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Jackie McLean]] â Musician, alto saxophone<ref name="HUSAmusic"/>*[[Malcolm X]] â Preacher, revolutionary *[[Earl Manigault]] â Basketball player *[[Thurgood Marshall]] â Supreme Court justice, lived at 409 Edgecombe Avenue.<ref name="maahcg"/><ref name="westharlemcpo"/> *[[Arthur Miller]] â playwright<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Moby]] â Musician, born in Harlem *[[Alice Neel]] â Artist, lived in East Harlem<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[Eleanor Holmes Norton]] â One-time head of the Commission of Human Rights for New York City, now non-voting Delegate from the District of Columbia to the United States House of Representatives. "There is something magical about Harlem."<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Gordon Parks]] â Film director and photographer<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Basil Paterson]] â New York state senator, New York City deputy mayor for labor relations, Vice-Chairman of the Democratic National Committee<ref name="ng1977"/><ref>"Harlem's Dreams Have Died in Last Decade, Leaders Say", ''New York Times,'' March 1, 1978. p.A1</ref> *[[Samuel Pierce]] - Ronald Reagan's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, lived in the Riverton Houses.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/nyregion/in-harlem-buildings-reminders-of-a-bubble-and-a-collapse.html "In Harlem Buildings, Reminders of Easy Money and the Financial Crisis,"] Charles V. Bagli, ''The New York Times,'' June 9, 2011</ref> *[[Adam Clayton Powell, Jr.]] â Politician *[[Bud Powell]] â Musician, pianist<ref name="HUSAmusic">"The Music of Harlem", William R. Dixon, in ''Harlem USA,'' ed. John Henrik Clarke, 1971, p. 136</ref> *[[Tito Puente, Sr.]] (April 20, 1923 â June 1, 2000), Musician Spanish Harlem *Isiah Robinson â One-time president of the New York City Board of Education<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Gene Anthony Ray]] â Dancer and actor<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0712833/bio IMDb bio for Gene Anthony Ray]</ref> *[[Sugar Ray Robinson]] â Boxer, Harlem entrepreneur. Moved to Harlem at age 12. *[[Sonny Rollins]] â Musician, tenor saxophone<ref name="HUSAmusic"/> *[[Steve Rossi]] â Comedian, former manager for [[Howard Stern]]<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0744326/bio Steve Rossi IMDB page]</ref> *[[Henry Roth]] â novelist<ref name="gillpost"/> *[[J. D. Salinger]] â Novelist, lived at 3681 Broadway until he was nine years old.<ref>[http://harlembespoke.blogspot.com/2010/01/walk-jd-salingers-childhood-home.html Harlem Bespoke]</ref> *[[Hazel Scott]] â Pianist, one-time wife of Adam Clayton Powell, Jr., first African American woman with her own television show.<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Nina Simone]] â Singer. Lived, for a time, in Duke Ellington's old house in Harlem.<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Thomas Sowell]] â Professional economist and author *[[Percy Sutton]] â One-time Borough President of Manhattan. "If I were offered a million dollars, I wouldn't leave Harlem."<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Billy Taylor]] - Jazz pianist, lived in the Riverton Houses.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/nyregion/in-harlem-buildings-reminders-of-a-bubble-and-a-collapse.html "In Harlem Buildings, Reminders of Easy Money and the Financial Crisis,"] Charles V. Bagli, ''The New York Times,'' June 9, 2011</ref> *[[Dinah Washington]] â "Queen of the Blues", born in Alabama but became famous when she lived in Harlem.<ref name="ng1977"/> *[[Roy Wilkins]] â Civil rights leader, lived at 409 Edgecombe.<ref name="maahcg"/> *[[Louis T. Wright]] â Influential physician, chairman of the board of the [[NAACP]]<ref name="bootsie"/> *[[Morrie Yohai]] â Rabbi, inventor of [[Cheez Doodles]].<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/03/business/03yohai.html "Morrie Yohai, 90, the Man Behind Cheez Doodles, Is Dead,"] Dennis Hevesi, ''The New York Times,'' August 2, 2010</ref>
== Rap, hip hop, R&B and reality == *[[Damon Dash]] â (CO-CEO of Splash entertainment) *[[Fatman Scoop]] â Grammy/MTV Award Winner/Radio Personality/Reality TV Star *[[DJ Red Alert]] â DJ/Hip Hop Pioneer *[[DJ Hollywood]] â VH-1 Hip Hop Honoree, & Rap/Hip Hop Pioneer *[[Kool Moe Dee]] â Old school rapper and one third of the [[Treacherous Three]] *[[Rob Base and DJ E-Z Rock]] â Rap duo best known for their hit "[[It Takes Two (Rob Base & DJ E-Z Rock song)|It Takes Two]]" *[[Freddie Jackson]] â Singer *[[Tupac Shakur]] â Deceased Rapper and actor *[[Big L (rapper)|Big L]] â Deceased rapper *[[Cam'ron]] â Rapper (Owner of Diplomat Records)(Dipset) *[[Crash Crew]] â Old school rap group *[[Jim Jones]] â Rapper (Co-CEO of Diplomat Records) (Dipset) *[[Sean Combs|Puff Daddy]] â Rapper/producer *[[ Alicia Keys]] â Singer/Songwriter *[[Fearless Four]] â Old school rap *[[Doug E. Fresh]] â 80's rapper, runs a waffle house in Harlem *[[Spoonie Gee]] â Old school rapper *[[Jae Millz]] â Rapper *[[Lil Mama]] â Rapper and judge of [[America's Best Dance Crew]] *[[Keith Sweat]] â Singer *[[Juelz Santana]] â Rapper (Owner/CEO of Skull Gang Records) *[[Mase]] â Rapper *[[Freekey Zekey]] â Rapper (Owner/CEO of 730 Dips Records) *[[Immortal Technique]] â Rapper *[[Kelis]] â R&B singer and songwriter *[[Biz Markie]] â Rapper/disc jockey *[[Cannibal Ox]] â Rap duo *[[Kurtis Blow]] â Rapper *[[40 Cal]] â Rapper *[[Billy Dee Williams]] â Actor *[[Yaya DaCosta]] â ANTM contestant/model *[[Bre Scullark]] â ANTM contestant/model *[[America's Next Top Model, Cycle 1|Ebony Haith]] â ANTM contestant/model *[[America's Next Top Model, Cycle 11|Sheena Sakai]] â ANTM contestant/model *[[Teddy Riley (producer)|Teddy Riley]]- Producer, artist *[[Isabel Sanford]]- Actor and Co-Star of [[The Jeffersons]] *[[Charles Hamilton (rapper)|Charles Hamilton]] â Rapper *[[Teyana Taylor]] â Singer, rapper, skater *[[Treacherous Three]] â Old school rap group *[[T-Rex]] â Rapper *[[Black Rob]]-Rapper from Spanish harlem. *[[Ilacoin]] -Hip Hop Artist, Creator of the "Pause" game *[[A$AP Rocky]]-Rapper From Harlem (Member of A$AP Mob crew) *[[Juelz Santana]] â Rapper (Co-CEO of Diplomat Records) (Dipset)
== 21st century residents == *[[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]] â Basketball player, moved into a Mount Morris brownstone at 30 West 120th Street<ref>[http://harlembespoke.blogspot.com/2011/08/dwell-30-west-120th-street-in-contract.html Harlem Bespoke]</ref> in September, 2006.<ref>"Kareem's Harlem digs", New York Daily News, September 10, 2006</ref> *[[Maya Angelou]] â Author, owns a home on 120th Street in Mount Morris Park district. "I never agreed with [[Thomas Wolfe]]. I never thought you canât go home again. I've been coming home to Harlem for 50 years."<ref>"A Revised Edition", Louis Tutelian, ''New York Times,'' January 5, 2007</ref> *[[Angela Bassett]] â [[Emmy]] and [[Academy Award]]-nominated actress, and [[Golden Globe]] winning actress. *[[Charlotte d'Amboise]] â actress and dancer. *[[Jonathan Franzen]] â Author, lived on 125th Street when he wrote his book ''The Corrections''<ref>[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20031018.HARLEM18/TPStory/Travel "Catching up with Harlem," Jean Cumming, TheGlobeAndMail.com Travel, October 18, 2003]</ref> *[[Marcia Gay Harden]] â Actress<ref name="NYMag20060814"/><ref>"Between Film Sets, Life on Gossamer Lake", Jill Capuzzo, ''The New York Times,'' September 14, 2007</ref> *[[Neil Patrick Harris]] - actor, lives near Morningside Park when not in Los Angeles.<ref>[http://harlembespoke.blogspot.com/2011/07/read-where-in-harlem-is-neil-patrick.html Harlem Bespoke]</ref> *[[Terrance Mann]] â actor and dancer. *[[Cameron Mathison]] â Actor on [[All My Children]] and contestant on [[Dancing with the Stars]], 136 West 130th Street<ref>[http://harlembespoke.blogspot.com/2009/03/meet-cameron-mathison.html] Harlem Bespoke]</ref><ref>[http://harlembespoke.blogspot.com/2011/07/dwell-mathison-brownstone-off-market.html Harlem Bespoke]</ref> *[[S. Epatha Merkerson]] â Actress <ref name="NYMag20060814"/> *[[Mandy Patinkin]] â Actor<ref name="NYMag20060814"/> *[[Adam Clayton Powell IV (politician)|Adam Clayton Powell IV]] â New York City council member *[[Marcus Samuelsson]] â Chef and restauranteur, living in a duplex near Frederick Douglass Boulevard as of 2010.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/08/dining/08rooster.html "Marcus Samuelsson Opens in Harlem,"] Glenn Collins, ''The New York Times,'' September 7, 2010</ref> *Akhnaten Spencer-El â Olympic fencer<ref>[http://www.edgate.com/copernedit/html/summergames/inactive/from_the_athlete/akhnaten_spencer-el.html Edgate]</ref> *[[Stephen Spinella]] â [[Tony Award]]-winning actor<ref>"Stephen Spinella's Real Estate Angels", Celia Barbour, ''New York Times,'' July 1, 2007</ref> *[[Joel Steinberg]] â Famously killed his adopted daughter, moved to Harlem after his 2004 release from prison<ref>"The monster now", The New York ''Daily News,'' July 10, 2006</ref> *[[Khalid Yasin]] â in Harlem, New York, raised in Brooklyn, is a teacher and lecturer of Islam. *[[Alton White]] â actor
